title: Patch Rundown 4.12 Comments and Questions
body:
Hey guys! This is the place to talk about what you saw on the first episode of many Patch Rundowns. Ask us questions about the show and the content, share your comments, and make your requests. Thanks for stopping by!

http://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/news/game-updates/patch/patch-rundown-412

replies.body: I like it! Make it a little bit shorter; focusing more on the "TL;DR" section with more gameplay videos, and focusing less on the discussion. Other than that, good job Riot!

I wonder if we're on an 'in-between' here where some people want more of the TLDR rundown and others just want more panel discussion. Someone's gonna ask "WHY NOT BOTH" but my question would be: what do you see the patch rundown as accomplishing? My guess is your answer is either:

a) A rundown of the changes made in the patch in a clear, digestable way (gameplay! summaries! video!)
b) Put a face to the design team, hear deeper context behind the changes we make and get a real deep-dive on our philosophy

We need more faces for Comics.

Definately Faces for the design team. For... Reasons...

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IIVbLgmElvA

Pwyff, you should distinguish between Patch Rundowns and Patch Previews, I feel.

PRs, like the one you just did, should be mostly about the panel discussion, especially on impactful and/or highly controversial changes.

PPs, like the old ones, delivered (and should deliver again, maybe?)  a congested, visual way of important changes, making them more clear to the community than a short text-only explanation would.

PRs for thoughts and discussion, PPs for visual explanation of changes.
both

I haven't actually watched the rundown yet, but I don't really get the point (or its just not for me) if it's basically a TLDR version of the patch notes. The patch notes are already very concise and, imo, easy to digest quickly. I would assume the Rundown would be a video of Riot going a lot more in-depth with the decisions they make and how they feel it will change the shape of the game.
I like b) i want to know what is inside of the heads of the design team. Also I would love to see Montecristo there, maybe before worlds or during the preseason.

> a) A rundown of the changes made in the patch in a clear, digestable way (gameplay! summaries! video!)

My question is, "What does this offer that can't be found anywhere else?" Most of it, can be found elsewhere, but I think there's one area that rundowns really stand out.

>video!

We can't see gameplay video of the new changes anywhere else; this should be the focus of the rundown (showcasing what champs can do with the changes).

One very real way that i think this would be helpful is in the case of changes that aren't necessarily straight nerfs. For example, the Kha'Zix changes a few patches ago. There were a lot of people complaining he had been gutted. A video highlighting his new weaknesses, and corresponding new strengths, I think would have gone a long way towards demonstrating to players that he can still do well.

> b) Put a face to the design team, hear deeper context behind the changes we make and get a real deep-dive on our philosophy

I feel like the "faces" part can be done in the rest of the forecast, and that Dev blogs are a better place for the rest of it. That being said, if there's a particularly controversial topic, like jungle timers, I think it's worth beating the proverbial dead horse.
I disagree just watch the TLDR at the start if you want the quick version I'd rather hear reds/pros discuss about the changes the way this video did.

Hi Markusbtw! Yes, Patch Rundown is a new series that will accompany each patch. So look out for Patch Rundown 4.13 in a couple weeks :)

I thought the video series has potential to be an amazing knowledge center for casual players. If you guys can produce bi-monthly videos on the state of the game (maybe a overview on how the patch affected the meta?), perhaps by highlighting new-found strengths, strategies, or champion roles, the video series will definitely take-off. And mspudding did a fantastic job! Well done rito :)
How about delaying Rundown a few days from patch notes and include questions from community?

I think that the patch rundown was cool. 

As to content: I'm only one person, so I don't think my opinion really matters that much. Instead, what matters is *how* you arrive at whatever decision you arrive at.

I think the question you should ask yourself is, "What does a patch rundown bring to the table that's unique?"

My personal feeling is, if I wanted to hear the rundown, I'd read the patch preview. If I wanted to hear the details, I'd read the patch notes. At the same time, there are people who'd rather hear it, or who just haven't seen the patch preview/notes. Therefore, my suggestion is to break the video into two parts:

1. Patch notes. in a little more depth than the tl;dr version in this rundown.
2. Discussion of said changes.

Because part 1 will be significantly longer, give people a link to the time where you swap over, so those of us who have already read the patch notes can quickly skip to the interesting part.

I see a few different voices in the comments section, so let me add mine: Make it longer! 

I can see why people prefer the shorter TL;DR: version. But both can be done, by starting off with the TL;DR: showing all the videos and the most important changes. But what interests me the most is the subsequent discussion about the changes. Why were they added? What is the reasoning behind them? What kind of design philosophy moves a given champion in a given direction? That's the important stuff, to understand why decisions are made. 

It helps us to understand what the goal of designers is with certain changes, and therefore also better understand what kind of a role a given champion is "expected" to fill. 

In any case, thanks for the rundown video! I like it, and can be longer as far as I'm concerned! :-)

I felt like in this one, the dissenting opinion of the one pro player was kinda shit down by all three Rioters very quickly explaining at once. If anyone with a negative or questioning opinion is gonna get shut down real quickly, make sure there's two or more people NOT on the design team present, or on the design team maybe with a different opinion. It felt a little like it was "team Riot vs This One Guy" for a couple of the points. 

By far, the girl presented the most polished, im-used- to-public-speaking persona there, while Statikk in particular came across as quite nervous and almost concerned about immediately getting defensive about each change discussed. Wôrk on relaxing more when called on to discuss changes, and I would ensure that you're not going off a ticking click- give the discussion a bit more time to go on.

I enjoyed the discussion greatly. I already see everything regarding patch notes from other sources so that specifically isn't filling a necessary void. It is nice to see an insider look from the balance team, sort of like what Phreak did before. It was also a great idea to have Snoopeh there to have the competitive knowledge. However, I have to say I much preferred listening to what Snoopeh had to say regarding the changes. Although very critical his logic seemed solid. I'd really like to see more professional players consulted before changes like these are made. What he says about inhibitors needing a timer before jungle camps is especially spot on. I'm not saying this because I am against jungle timers, in fact I've come to enjoy it although it does make the game simpler leaving less of a skill gap between newer and experienced players. It was said in this discussion that jungle timers were something considered for implementation for quite some time, however most people know that the real motivator behind doing so was Curse Voice. Whether or not it had been considered beforehand isn't really the point, if it wasn't for the Curse Voice application controversy this likely would have taken much more time. It's nice to know that the community is being listened to, but I feel like putting the games into the hands of the community is less effective than putting it into the hands of the competitive knowledge base. League of Legends is an E-Sport, the people playing at the highest level do have some idea of what makes the game work, and ways to make it continue to work. This improves quality of life for the casual fanbase, the most important part of the game financially, however making the game feel more alive for the top competitors is what will really make League of Legends a better choice for a sport. Please listen to your competitive audience! I'd love to see even more pro players involved in these discussions talking directly to the development team. A good debate is great for transparency! Keep up the great work.
